revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Organizations|date=March 2016}} {{COI|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization |image=File:FCC LOGO BLACK LINE.png |name=Full Contact Championship |founded=2009 |founder=Prashant Kumar |leader_title=Directors |leader_name=Binoy Khimji
Joy Kapur |parent_organization=Full Contact Entertainment Pvt. Ltd |headquarters=Mumbai, India |website={{URL|www.fccmma.in}} }} [[File:Directors of FCC.jpg|thumb|281x281px|'''Directors of FCC:''' From Left - Binoy Khimji, Joy Kapur, Prashant Kumar]]'''Full Contact Championship''' (FCC) is India's longest{{Cite web|url=http://www.mmamania.com/2012/6/6/3067983/indias-longest-running-mma-promotion-returns-to-mumbai-for-full|title=India's Longest Running MMA Promotion Returns to Mumbai For Full Contact Championship 6|website=MMAmania.com|access-date=2016-03-28}} running professional [[mixed martial arts]] fight network. Founded in 2009, under the banner of Full Contact Entertainment Pvt. Ltd, FCC is India's first pro MMA organization.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-for-the-first-time-india-will-witness-the-form-of-mixed-martial-arts-1243519|title=For the first time, India will witness the form of mixed martial arts|website=dnaindia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-28}} FCC has been sanctioned by Mixed Martial Arts Association of India and has followed the usual "Fight Night" format. It is one of the MMA organisations, formed to promote the sport of MMA in India and globally. Till date, FCC has had 13 fight nights; the most recent one being held at Indore on 9 July 2016 by the name of FCC-13.{{Cite web|url=https://allevents.in/mumbai/fcc-12-full-contact-championship/1689821751259853|title=FCC 12 (Full Contact Championship)|website=allevents.in|access-date=2016-03-28}} == Management Team == # Prashant Kumar {{Cite web|url=http://theringsideview.com/interview-with-prashant-kumar-of-the-full-combat-championship-fcc/|title=Interview With Chandan Of The Full Combat Championship (FCC) {{!}}|website=theringsideview.com|access-date=2016-03-28}} - Founder & Director - Prashant is a Mixed Martial Arts expert who participated in Free Style Fighting in Mumbai in the early 90's. Prashant has a Black Belt in [[Taekwondo]], has trained in [[Kickboxing]], [[Muay Thai]], and has also cross trained in [[Grappling]] and [[Judo]]. # Binoy Khimji{{Cite web|url=https://www.mumbaiangels.com/mumbai_angels_individual_catgry.php?prfid=MQ==&member=NTQ=|title=Mumbai Angels - Individual Members|website=www.mumbaiangels.com|access-date=2016-03-28}} - Director # Joy Kapur - Director == FCC Fight Nights == Since 2009, FCC has produced 13 fight nights. Their occurrence has been in the following order: {| class="wikitable" |Fight Night |Venue |City |- |FCC-1 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-2 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-3 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-4 |Filmalaya Studio, Andheri |Mumbai |- |FCC-5 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-6 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-7 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-8 |Vagator Hill Top, Vagator |Goa |- |FCC-9 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-10 |Vagator Hill Top, Vagator |Goa |- |FCC-11 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-12 |Famous Studios, Mahalaxmi |Mumbai |- |FCC-13 |Basketball Complex, |Indore |} == Rules == FCC's current rules are based upon the ''[[Unified Rules of Mixed Martial Arts]]'' that were originally established by the [[New Jersey State Athletic Control Board]] and modified by the [[Nevada State Athletic Commission]]. == Cage == FCC uses a 6 sided Hexagon cage for its fights. This cage was introduced in FCC-12. Prior to FCC-12, the fights took place in a square ring. == FCC-12 == FCC-12 took place at Famous Studios, Mumbai on 29 January 2016. This was by far the biggest of FCC fight nights. This event marked the introduction of a hexagon fight cage into FCC. The fight night saw a total of 9 bouts, including a wild card entry bout as well. Wali "The Warrior",{{Cite web|url=http://www.sherdog.com/fighter/Ahmed-Wali-Hotak-157679|title=Ahmed Wali Hotak|last=Sherdog.com|website=Sherdog|access-date=2016-03-31}} an Afghani mixed martial artist was the winner of the Main Event Bout, beating Mumbai's "Furious" Farhan. FCC-12 had a telecast on [[DD Sports]] and was widely covered by a lot of print, online and television media. It had online ticket sales on Bookmyshow and had partnered with [[Fever 104 FM]] for Radio Promotions. During the FCC-12 Fight Night, the founder Prashant Kumar{{Cite web|url=http://thefangarage.com/articles/5972-an-iconic-mma-hero-is-needed-from-india--in-coversation-with-fcc-founder-prashanth-kumar|title=Interview of FCC founder Prashanth Kumar by Renjith Ravindran {{!}}{{!}}The Fan Garage (TFG)|last=|first=|date=2016-06-29|website=The Fan Garage|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-11}} announced FCC League{{Cite web|url=http://www.starworldnews.co/full-contact-entertainment-unveiled-fcc/|title=Full Contact Entertainment unveiled FCC|website=Star World News|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-28}} - World's First ever MMA League. FCC league will be a 7 city team based league and will consist of 7 fighters in each team, one being an international fighter. == FCC-13 == The team of FCC announced their 13th fight night in Indore and organized the same on 9 July 2016. A total of 12 bouts took place in this fight night. The media announcement was made on SR Media, a local TV channel and the venue for the same was Basketball Complex, Indore. The event saw a crowd of more than 2000 people flocking the stadium to witness FCC-13. [[Elli Avram]] was the guest of honor and Deep Money performed live at the fight night. FCC-13 featured 3 India v Afghanistan bouts. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Mixed martial arts organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in India]]

{{infobox company | name = Gamerizon | logo = | caption = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada ({{Start date|2008}})[http://www.develop-online.net/news/31274/Gamerizon-opens-doors/ Gamerizon opens doors]. Retrieved February 10, 2009. | founder = Martin Lizée, Robert Lizée & Dominique Bélanger | defunct = | location_city = [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada | location_country = [[Canada]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Alex Sakiz ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/gadgets-and-tech/11/08/10/iphone-triggers-videogame-gold-rush iPhone Gold Rush]. Retrieved August 11, 2010.
Martin Lizée (Co-founder and [[Chief Creative Officer]])
Robert Lizée (Co-founder and [[Chief Technical Officer]])
Geri-Lynn Kushneryk ([[Chief Financial Officer]]) | industry = [[Video games]] | products = "[[Chop Chop Ninja]]", "[[Chop Chop Runner]]", "[[Chop Chop Tennis]]", "[[Chop Chop Soccer]]", "[[Chop Chop Hockey]]", "'[[Chop Chop Caveman]]", "[[Chop Chop Kicker]]", "[[Chop Chop Rocket]]", "[[Chop Chop Slicer]]", "[[Chop Chop Ninja World]]" | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 30 [https://montrealgazette.com/life/Gamerizon+early+start+pays/5410822/story.html Early start pays off] | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.gamerizon.com/ gamerizon.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Gamerizon''' is a [[video game developer]] and publisher headquartered in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada. Gamerizon develops games for [[iPhone]] and [[iPad]]. The company's most profitable products on the [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]] and include{{vague|date=August 2016}} "[[Chop Chop Ninja]]", "Chop Chop Runner", "Chop Chop Tennis" and "Chop Chop Caveman". According to Gamerizon, 15 million "Chop Chop" games have been downloaded so far on the App Store and six of those have been downloaded a million times each.[http://gamerizon.com/2011/09/15/montreal-based-mobile-game-studio-gamerizon-closes-five-million-dollars-investment-round/ 15 million games] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419214059/http://gamerizon.com/2011/09/15/montreal-based-mobile-game-studio-gamerizon-closes-five-million-dollars-investment-round/ |date=April 19, 2012 }} Gamerizon's Chop Chop series are easily recognizable by the cartoony look of their big-headed characters. In an interview to video game magazine [[PocketGamer]], Alex Sakiz revealed the company’s ambition to expand the Chop Chop Franchise to 20 games and 40 million downloads.[http://www.pocketgamer.biz/r/PG.Biz/Gamerizon+news/news.asp?c=27401 Pocket Gamer Interview] In the same interview, he mentioned the Chop Chop games will be available on Android phones and possibly on other platforms. In March 2011, Gamerizon was named 32nd on [[PocketGamer]]‘s Top 50 App Developers.[http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Multiformat/Pocket+Gamer/news.asp?c=27842 Top 50 App Developers] On September 15 of 2011, Gamerizon announced they have closed a 5 million dollars first round investment with Vanedge Capital and iNovia Capital. The Montreal-based studio will be looking to hire 100 employees within 2 years.[https://montrealgazette.com/business/Gamerizon+secures+funding/5407228/story.html Gamerizon secures funding] In March 2012, Gamerizon announced their new project at the [[Game Developers Conference]]. Chop Chop Ninja World will be the first social [[freemium]] action [[platformer]] on both [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].[http://www.gamezebo.com/games/chop-chop-ninja-world/preview Chop Chop Ninja World Preview] Subsequently, Gamerizon was named by Pocket Gamer in its Top 10 Mobile Game Developers to Watch in 2012.[http://www.pocketgamer.biz/r/PG.Biz/PG.Biz+Top+50+Developers+2012/feature.asp?c=38352h Top 10 Mobile Game Developers to Watch in 2012] Gamerizon announced on its Facebook page in October that the game will be released worldwide on November 29. In April 2012, Gamerizon announced Iro, the main character of their hit-game Chop Chop Ninja, will be the star of his own [[animated series]] on the Canadian channel [[Teletoon (Canadian TV channel)|Teletoon]] and will air at the Fall of 2014.[http://gamerizon.com/2012/04/10/2218/ Chop Chop ninja: From Game to Fame] In May 2012, Gamerizon's CEO Alex Sakiz was named in C2-MTL's Top 25 Emerging Entrepreneurs.{{cite web |url=http://c2mtl.com/and-the-25-winners-of-the-emerging-entrepreneurs-contest-are/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510172607/http://c2mtl.com/and-the-25-winners-of-the-emerging-entrepreneurs-contest-are/ |archivedate=2012-05-10 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gamerizon.com/ Official website] [[Category:Companies based in Montreal]] [[Category:Companies established in 2008]] [[Category:Video game companies of Canada]] [[Category:Video game publishers]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Digitalmusician.jpeg|alt=Digitalmusician.net|thumb|Two musicians collaborating on Digitalmusician.net]] --> An '''Internet band''', also called an '''online band''', is a [[musical group]] whose members collaborate online through broadband by utilizing a content management system and local [[digital audio workstation]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/virtual-band.htm|title=What is a virtual band?|author=|date=2 July 2008|website=HowStuffWorks.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> The work is sometimes released under a [[Creative Commons]] license, so musicians can share their "samples" to create collaborative musical expressions for noncommercial purposes without ever meeting face to face.
==History==
=== Cathedral === In March 1996, Nora Farrell and [[William Duckworth (composer)|William Duckworth]] began to develop Cathedral, one of the first interactive works of music and art on the World Wide Web. Their aim was to create an interactive website with web-based musical instruments that anyone could play. Also in the preliminary stages of the system, they determined that they wanted to make a place on the Web for acoustic music through a series of live webcasts and performances online.
In June 1997, Cathedral went live online. The first build of this system included streaming audio, streaming video, animation, images, and text. At the time, there were fewer than one million sites on the World Wide Web and fewer than 2% of those made any sounds.
According to the creators of Cathedral, their goals at that point were: * To create an imaginative, ongoing artistic experience that builds community. * To blur the distinctions that separate composers, performers, and audiences. * To offer each individual listener the ability to create his or her own unique work online. By 2003, Cathedral consisted of three primary components: * A website that featured a variety of interactive musical, artistic, and text-based experiences. * A group of virtual instruments that allowed listeners to participate actively and creatively. * An Internet band that gave periodic live performances and offered listeners focused moments in which to come together and play music in community online.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Perceptual and Structural Implications of "Virtual" Music on the Web|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1196/annals.1284.036/abstract|journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|date = 2003-11-01|issn = 1749-6632|pages = 254–262|volume = 999|issue = 1|doi = 10.1196/annals.1284.036|first = William|last = Duckworth}}</ref>
==Current scenario== Social networking sites have gained a large number of users because many aspects of society revolve around computers and the Internet. The music industry itself has undergone this change as well. People are using iTunes, YouTube and MySpace Music to share the music and communicate with others. Adaptively, artists and record labels can utilize Web sites and file sharing sites to spread their music. Musicians who use the Internet can also form bands online.
Internet bands became popular in the early 2000s when music technology, file sharing and collaboration software became more prevalent on the Internet. While the extent of collaboration between bands may vary, an Internet band identifies as a band whose members collaborate on music projects via the Internet.
A growing number of websites offer people the opportunity to compose music online. They marry social networking with music mixing and uploading technology. Users decide what projects they wish to add their special touches to and how actively they want to get involved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/virtual-band.htm/|title=What is a virtual band?|author=|date=2 July 2008|website=HowStuffWorks.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="deadclowns.com">{{cite web|url=http://deadclowns.com/index.php?page=/about.php|title=The Dead Clowns|author=|date=|website=The Dead Clowns|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref>
==Advantages== The advantages of joining an [[online band]] include the ability to collaborate with musicians, vocalists, [[audio engineers]], etc. who reside in any part of the world with [[Internet access]]. Also, since many online bands do not perform or record in "real-time", it allows members to record their track (their part of a collaboration) at their leisure.<ref name="deadclowns.com"/>
=== Education through online music collaboration === In addition to setting a platform to creatively collaborate with other musicians, online music collaboration gives opportunities to educators and students that were not possible before its conception. This platform provides an alternative to the traditional 1:1 music lesson, but its effectiveness on a higher scale is questionable.
Research conducted in 2007 at [[Boston University]] led by [[musicologist]] and comparative educationist [[David G. Hebert]] provided five key challenges for online music education programs: # Prejudice regarding the legitimacy of online degrees # Coordination between distance education and music departments # Pressure to maximize profits at the expense of educational quality # Management of adjunct music instructors # Management of student behavior and provision of student services To address these challenges, Hebert pointed out the importance of expert mentors, outstanding research theses completed online, a strong record of graduate job placement from online programs, detailed planning between instructors and music departments, and the implementation of assessment moderation systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ814926.pdf|title = Five Challenges and Solutions in Online Music Teacher Education|last = Hebert|first = David G.|date = September 2007|journal = Research and Issues in Music Education|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
==Collaboration== Online music collaboration is an Internet-based system designed to help coordinate online music projects. Most platforms provide a virtual space to upload recorded music files, a community forum where members can offer feedback or make alterations to the uploaded music.
Each musician usually needs to record to a click track or metronome and upload the instrument or vocals for the song independently. Then a designated Internet music producer can edit for timing and tightness between all tracks, arrange, optimize and mix all instruments together and do a final mastering process to get a complete song out of single tracks.
== Related phenomenon == Internet-based music collaboration can be done by individuals who never form one permanent band. The [[Playing for Change]] Foundation is a musical charity that releases music recorded by musicians from all around the globe, only some of whom have gone on to play together live. Even more decentralized collaboration happens between YouTube users; one ''[[Cracked (magazine)|Cracked]]'' columnist praised the cover of the ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' theme performed by violinist Jason Yang and guitarist and sound engineer Roger Lima and directed by Paolo Dy.{{quote|And these people have never met. The Internet isn't just causing collaborations between people who would otherwise never have got together, it's creating collaborations between people who still haven't got together. There's just so much creativity being uploaded that we've reached collaboration critical-mass, where mixes can be generated across the world with nothing but HTTP. The result is a "super-feit" -- a copy superior to the original.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cracked.com/blog/5-music-videos-that-justify-existence-internet/#ixzz2AWxUYQCe|title=5 Music Videos That Justify the Existence of the Internet|author=|date=|website=Cracked.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref>}}
== Internet band communities == Internet bands develop online and base the foundations their work within various communities. The systems below are examples of communities which support the formation and maintenance of online bands: * BANDMIX<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bandmix.com|title=Musicians Wanted - Search Local Musician Classifieds : BandMix.com|author=|date=|website=www.BandMix.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is the highest rated and largest "musicians wanted" and musicians classifieds online. It has a search function that enables users to find musicians and bands by instrument and zip code. It also allows users to browse the musicians and bands by state within the United States. * Digitalmusician.net<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalmusician.net/|title=Digital Musician|author=|date=|website=DigitalMusician.net|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is a real-time audio and MIDI collaboration system for Mac and PC that provides video chat functionality and the exchange of big audio files. The company is partnered with [[Steinberg]], [[Native Instruments]], and [[Ableton]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Digitalmusician.net Goes Public: Online Music Collaboration - Create Digital Music|url = http://createdigitalmusic.com/2005/08/digitalmusiciannet-goes-public-online-music-collaboration/|website = Create Digital Music|access-date = 2 December 2015|language = en-US}}</ref> * Join My Band<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joinmyband.co.uk|title=Join My Band - Musicians Wanted/Available, Find Band Members Online|author=|date=|website=www.JoinMyBand.co.uk|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is the UK's most popular musicians classifieds site. It can help users in the UK find local partners. It classifies the category by location. Anyone in the UK could successfully find something useful to them if they want to join a local band. In addition, Join My Band provides discussion forums which include music and music-making. * Kompoz<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kompoz.com/music/home|title=Kompoz Music Collaboration|author=|date=|website=Kompoz|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is a global artist community. It establishes a focus on digital audio workstation users and promotes recording collaboration over live performance collaborations. Users are able to upload song ideas to the site and invite others to join. They can collaborate through that or even form a band. * My Online Band<ref>{{cite web|url=http://myonlineband.com|title=MyOnlineBand.com - Online Music Collaboration and Virtual Bands|author=|date=|website=MyOnlineBand.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is an online community that allows users to create a workspace to attract other users, publish their own songs, and listen to others’ music for free. Users can formally join a band through the site's “join a band” functionality. Users can access a list of bands, including what kind of member they are seeking and how to contact them. * BlogBand<ref>{{cite web|url=http://myblogband.com|title=- Myblogband, Collaborate Online in A Global Workspace in a Band that You Start or Join. Register to Download Free .mp3 Tracks from Independent Bands and Musicians|author=|date=|website=MyBlogBand.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is a social network for musicians to collaborate online. Users can create a profile, create a band, create a song, and then upload, download, rework or repost tracks into the song file, selecting which version of the song they want to be the default song. Patents US8487173 and US20140040119 were issued and cover many collaborative functions of the social network for musicians with more features coming soon.{{When|date=September 2017}} * ProCollabs<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.procollabs.com|title=ProCollabs - Make Music Online - Collaborate - Hire Artists - ProCollabs.com|author=|date=|website=www.ProCollabs.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> is an exclusive 'members-only' online music collaboration service that provides a global platform for international artists, songwriters, producers, and audio engineers to be able to meet, socialize, collaborate and produce original music.
==Examples of Internet bands== * The ClipBandits, known as "the first Internet band", collaborated without ever having met each other,<ref>Lore Sjoberg, [http://archive.wired.com/table_of_malcontents/2006/10/the_clipbandits/ "The ClipBandits — Internet Band,"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', October 17, 2006.</ref> were featured on ABC World News and ''Good Morning America'', and ultimately met and performed on [[the Tyra Banks Show]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clipbandits.com|title=ClipBandits - The World's First Internet Band - Created by Nick Matzorkis|author=|date=|website=www.ClipBandits.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * Frozen Coco (former online rock band quartet, hailing from UK, US and Chile; music catalog consists of 21 tracks)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Frozen Coco|url = https://frozencoco.bandcamp.com/|website = Frozen Coco|access-date = 19 February 2016}}</ref> * Slice the Cake (three-piece deathcore band; vocalist living in England, bassist living in Australia and guitarist-programmer living in Sweden)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/stcproject/info?ref=page_internal|title=Slice The Cake|author=|date=|website=www.Facebook.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * Decimated Humans (slam death metal band; vocalist living in Nevada USA, guitarist-bassist living in Australia and drummer living in Maine, USA)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/DecimatedHumans/|title=DECIMATED HUMANS|author=|date=|website=www.Facebook.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * Swine Overlord (slam death metal band from Florida and New York)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethecoffin.com/ReviewSWINEOVERLORDPARABLESOFUMBRALTRANSCENDANCE/|title=insidethecoffin.com|author=|date=|website=InsideTheCoffin.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * Malodorous (death metal band with several members residing in numerous parts of the USA)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://malodorous.bandcamp.com/album/augury-of-the-aborted|title=Augury Of The Aborted, by Malodorous|author=|date=|website=Malodorous|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * [[Infant Annihilator]] (three-member deathcore band; two members living in Hull, UK, and vocalist living in Florida, USA; ex-vocalist from Indiana, USA)<ref>{{cite web|author=Alex Lee|url=http://www.megustareviews.com/2013/01/infant-annihilator-palpable-leprosy-2012.html|title=Infant Annihilator - The Palpable Leprosy... (2012)|website=www.MegustaReviews.com|access-date=15 April 2018|date=2012}}</ref> * Electric Rats (blues rock-garage rock Internet band from post-USSR (Russia and Ukraine))<ref>{{cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/electricrats|title=soundcloud.com|author=|date=|website=SoundCloud.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> * Spicy Folk, with music published and sold globally on Amazon and iTunes work from the UK and USA and formed after having met on an online music collaboration site, ProCollabs.com <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.procollabs.com|title=ProCollabs - Make Music Online - Collaborate - Hire Artists - ProCollabs.com|author=|date=|website=www.ProCollabs.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Virtual Band]]
==References== {{reflist|1}}
[[Category:Types of musical groups]] <!--Category:Internet is about the internet, NOT its use --> [[Category:Virtual communities]] [[Category:Music websites]] [[Category:Musical terminology]] [[Category:Computer-mediated communication]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = It's Magic, Charlie Brown | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = Animated TV Special | creator = [[Charles M. Schulz]] | director = [[Phil Roman]] | creative_director = | developer = | presenter = | starring = | voices = [[Sydney Penny]]
Cindi Reilly
Earl Reilly
[[Bill Melendez]]
Michael Mandy
Shannon Cohn
Brent Hauer
Casey Carlson | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = [[Ed Bogas]]
[[Judy Munsen]] | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = [[Lee Mendelson]] | producer = Bill Melendez | company = [[Marvel Productions]] | runtime = 27 minutes | network = [[CBS]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = April 28, 1981 | last_aired = | preceded_by = ''[[Life Is a Circus, Charlie Brown]]'' | followed_by = ''[[Someday You'll Find Her, Charlie Brown]]'' | related = | website = }} '''''It's Magic, Charlie Brown''''' is the 21st [[prime-time]] [[animation|animated]] [[TV special]] based upon the [[comic strip]] ''[[Peanuts]],'' by [[Charles M. Schulz]]. It originally aired on April 28, 1981. The special was later released on DVD on September 2, 2008 as a bonus feature on [[Warner Home Video]]'s remastered deluxe DVD of ''[[It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown]]''.[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Charlie-Brown-Peanuts-Specials-Great-Pumpkin/9890 Charlie Brown/Peanuts Specials DVD news: Rear Box Art for It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown: Remastered Deluxe Edition | TVShowsOnDVD.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016212655/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Charlie-Brown-Peanuts-Specials-Great-Pumpkin/9890 |date=2008-10-16 }} == Plot summary == Charlie Brown decides that Snoopy needs to educate himself, and gives him his library card to check out a few books. Snoopy decides to take out one book, a book about magic, which after reading, influences him to hold a Vaudeville show (under the stage name "The Great [[Harry Houdini|Houndini]]"). During the opening, Snoopy practices magic with Woodstock by his side. Charlie Brown warns both of them that the cat next door will get upset if he and Woodstock get really loud. However, Snoopy and Woodstock continue to perform more magic tricks and the cat next door angrily rips Snoopy's doghouse apart. He recruits Marcie as one assistant and announcer, and Sally as his silent assistant. In the show, he pulls a rabbit out of his hat (actually Woodstock with rabbit ears), then does a ring trick that goes wrong. Both of these tricks raise the ire of one heckler who demands their money back and does not see the humor the others see, but Snoopy quickly shuts him up both times. He also does the "stick-in-the-hole" trick to Franklin, the "amputation-decapitation" trick to Peppermint Patty, cutting Linus's trademark security blanket into strips (which appears to fail), the levitation trick to Lucy van Pelt, and biggest of all, making Charlie Brown literally disappear. A sudden rainstorm ends the show early, and Charlie Brown is left invisible. Convinced he is going to remain that way for the rest of his life, he prepares to roam the world as a lost soul, and Sally begins moving her stuff into his room. Before Charlie starts roaming, he decides to feed Snoopy to show him what has happened. When Snoopy realizes he cannot yet reverse the trick, he tries a couple of different ideas to make Charlie Brown somewhat visible again, including draping a sheet over his head and scaring Sally, and when Charlie Brown looks in the mirror and sees that Snoopy made him a ghost, he faints. Despite this shortcoming, Charlie Brown realizes he has a golden opportunity to kick Lucy's infamous football without her usual prank of pulling it away at the last second. Taking advantage of his invisibility, Charlie Brown finally kicks the ball out of a bewildered Lucy's hand and then taunts her about it. Furious over Charlie Brown succeeding in kicking the ball, Lucy gets the magic book back to give to Snoopy, threatening that if he doesn't make Charlie Brown visible again, she'll pound him. After starting out by entering his doghouse lab and working with chemicals so volatile, they explode and start a chain reaction of explosions that chase him out of the house, Snoopy continues to study the book, and tests a number of counterspells on Woodstock (making his feet bigger, then head bigger, then making him disappear, but successfully reversing each spell), he goes about casting his counterspell in all directions, unsure just where Charlie Brown is. As Snoopy wanders into a vicinity where Lucy is setting up another place-kick, Charlie Brown happens to run by where Snoopy is practicing. Just as he is about to kick the ball again, Snoopy casts the counterspell in Charlie Brown's direction, causing him to unknowingly become visible again. Lucy witnesses his reappearance and pulls the ball away for the eleventh time as Charlie Brown winds up to kick it, then promptly falls on his back. However, Charlie Brown fails to display embarrassment and says that he finally kicked the ball, though Lucy considers this a false statement, saying no one will believe him. When Lucy scoffs at Snoopy's magic abilities, the insulted beagle magically levitates Lucy into the sky like he levitated her during the magic show earlier, and leaves her stuck there as payback. Snoopy and Charlie Brown laugh and happily dance away to conclude a satisfying day, ignoring Lucy's pleas to get her down. Linus eventually pulls Lucy down with his blanket during the closing credits, and Lucy, angry and embarrassed about what happened, gives up and stomps away. == Cast == * Michael Mandy: [[Charlie Brown]] * [[Sydney Penny]]: [[Lucy van Pelt]] * Cindi Reilly: [[Sally Brown]] * Earl Reilly: [[Linus van Pelt]] and [[Franklin (Peanuts)|Franklin]] * Brent Hauer: [[Peppermint Patty]] * Shannon Cohn/Casey Carlson: [[Marcie]] * Christopher Donohone: [[Schroeder (Peanuts)|Schroeder]] * [[Bill Melendez]]: [[Snoopy]] and [[Woodstock (Peanuts)|Woodstock]] == Note == * Production completed at [[Marvel Productions]]. == References == == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0082570|title=It's Magic, Charlie Brown}} {{Peanuts television specials}} [[Category:Peanuts television specials]] [[Category:Films directed by Phil Roman]] [[Category:1980s American television specials]] [[Category:1981 television specials]] [[Category:1981 in American television]] [[Category:CBS television specials]] [[Category:Films about magic and magicians]]

page.title: Knights of the Dinner Table Illustrated

revision.comment: minor fixes, mostly [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|disambig links]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=November 2008}} [[File:KotD Illustrated 01 cover.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Cover of the 1st issue.]] '''Knights of the Dinner Table Illustrated''' (a.k.a. ''K.ILL'') is a [[comic book]] created by [[Jolly R. Blackburn]] and is published by [[Kenzer & Company]]. It portrays many of the same stories as [[Knights of the Dinner Table]] (KODT) but from the point of view of the player characters themselves.
The first monthly issue was published in June 2000.
The comic was suddenly cancelled seemingly mid-story with issue #41 when suddenly (in strip) the "set" which the characters were "acting" on was knocked over. The "director" then informs the "cast" that the series was cancelled due to a lack of sales. There was no other explanation listed within the book other than the movie set parody listed in strip.
==Characters== The comic centers on the ''Untouchable Trio (plus one)'': the battlemage '''Teflon Billy''', the fighter '''El Ravager''' and the thief '''Knuckles, King of the Wallclimbers'''. Initially the ''plus one'' was the barbarian '''Zayre''', who eventually departed and was replaced by '''Thorina'''.
The comic occasionally follows the adventures the Black Hands and other characters from KODT, sometimes in other universes (e.g. Cyberhack).
K.ILL is strictly and humorously faithful to the concept that its characters are experiencing reality, and are not merely characters in a role-playing game. Some of the humor stems from the explanations that the characters give for events that, in KODT, stem from the gameplayers' mundane commitments or, in reality, from the comic's business decisions. For example, when Bob (in KODT) is unable to game for a while, Knuckles (in K.ILL) is unavailable due to commitments to his Guild. When K.ILL's artists changed in issue 4, the characters experience and comment on the alteration in their appearance as the result of a ''[[Werner Heisenberg|Hazenberg]]'s Dimension Shifting Portal of Chaos''. K.ILL is noticeably more graphically violent than KODT, even while depicting the same event, since in the latter the in-game violence is represented only by dialogue.
==Contributors== * Development Team: [[Jolly R. Blackburn]], [[Brian Jelke]], [[Steve Johansson]], [[David S. Kenzer]] * Writer: Issues 1-4 - Aaron Williams, [[Jolly R. Blackburn]], [[Brian Jelke]], [[Steve Johansson]], [[David S. Kenzer]] * Writer: Issues 8-41 - [[Mark Plemmons]]. Earlier issues in this run are often based on ideas by [[Jolly R. Blackburn]] and other members of the development team, with more original stories as the series progressed. * Art: ** Issues 1-4 - Aaron Williams ** Issues 4-41 - [[Brian Fraim]], [[Brendon Fraim]]
==See also== * [[Nodwick]], another [[role-playing game|roleplaying]] [[comic strip]] * [[Dork Tower]], another [[role-playing game|roleplaying]] [[comic strip]] * [[Order of the Stick]], another [[role-playing game|roleplaying]] [[comic strip]]
==External links== * [http://www.kenzerco.com/ Official KODT homepage]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Knights Of The Dinner Table Illustrated}} [[Category:Comics publications]] [[Category:Fantasy comics]]

{{Infobox company | name = Lambiek | logo = | type = [[Direct market|Comic book store]], [[art museum|art gallery]] | industry = [[Comic book]]s, [[art]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|1968|11|8}} | founder = Kees Kousemaker | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Amsterdam]] | hq_location_country = [[Netherlands]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = [[Kees Kousemaker]], Boris Kousemaker | products = Comic books | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{URL|lambiek.com}} }}
'''Galerie Lambiek''' is a Dutch [[direct market|comic book store]] and art gallery in [[Amsterdam]], founded on November 8, 1968<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/dutchcomics/1968.htm|title=Dutch Comics 1968 -1979|publisher=}}</ref> by {{Interlanguage link multi|Kees Kousemaker|nl}}. From 1968 to 2015 it was located in the Kerkstraat, but in November 2015 the store moved to the Koningsstraat 27.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/news/284/comicshop_lambiek_moves_from_kerkstraat_132_to_koningsstraat_27.html#.VotTiFLxuNI|title=Comicshop Lambiek moves from Kerkstraat 132 to Koningsstraat 27|work=Lambiek Comic Shop}}</ref>. As of 2018, Lambiek is the oldest comics store in Europe <ref>http://www.comicon.com/2018/10/11/happy-50th-to-europes-oldest-comic-shop-lambiek-in-amsterdam/</ref> and the oldest worldwide still in existence. <ref>http://www.valiseetparapluie.com/2016/12/lambiek-the-worlds-oldest-comics-shop/</ref> <ref>https://indianexpress.com/article/news-archive/web/memories-are-made-of-these/</ref>
The Lambiek website is one of the longest-running resources about comics and cartoonists on the Internet. The website features a web shop for comic books, eComics, and original art,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/webshop.html|title=Comic books for sale in Lambiek's webshop - Lambiek Comic Shop|publisher=}}</ref> as well as a news page with articles of interest to comics fans<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/news/comic_fan_news.html|title=News overview|publisher=}}</ref> and online art exhibitions. The flagship of the site is the ''Comiclopedia'', an illustrated compendium of over 13,700 international comic artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comiclopedia.html|title=Comiclopedia - Illustrated artist compendium - Lambiek Comiclopedia|work=lambiek.net}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net8" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_online_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek - Lambiek at Lambiek.net (1999-2004) |publisher=}}</ref> The site also features a history of [[Dutch comics]], mostly researched and written by Kees Kousemaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/infomenu/faq.html?fcategory=Comiclopedia&fid=127|title=Lambiek Comic Shop|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/dutchcomics/|title=Introduction|publisher=}}</ref>
The name "Lambiek" originated as a misspelling of the name of the comics character [[Lambik]], from the popular [[Suske & Wiske]] comic book series created by [[Belgium|Belgian]] artist [[Willy Vandersteen]].<ref name="lambiek.net">{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/v/vandersteen.htm|title=Willy Vandersteen|date=1 January 1970|work=lambiek.net}}</ref> The logo of the shop is an image from the ''Suske en Wiske'' album ''Prinses Zagemeel'' (''Princess Sawdust'').<ref name="lambiek.net"/>
The store has held art exhibitions and book signings by comic creators, including [[Gilbert Shelton]], [[Will Eisner]] <ref name= "lambiek.net4" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1980-1985)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net6" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_3.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1990-1995)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Tanino Liberatore]], [[Joost Swarte]], [[Peter Pontiac]] <ref name= "lambiek.net5" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1986-1989)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>., [[Don Lawrence]] <ref name= "lambiek.net6" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_3.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1990-1995)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[André Franquin]], [[Robert Crumb]] <ref name= "lambiek.net6" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_3.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1990-1995)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Lorenzo Mattotti]] <ref name= "lambiek.net6" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_3.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1990-1995)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Charles Burns (cartoonist)|Charles Burns]] <ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Daniel Clowes]]<ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref> , [[Jim Woodring]] <ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Chris Ware]] <ref name= "lambiek.net7" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_4.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1996-2003)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Judith Vanistendael]] <ref name= "lambiek.net10" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2005-2010)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Marc Bell (cartoonist)|Marc Bell]] <ref name= "lambiek.net10" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2005-2010)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Jillian Tamaki]] and [[Mariko Tamaki]] <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[David Collier (cartoonist)|David Collier]] <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Glen Baxter (cartoonist)|Glen Baxter]] <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Jaromír Švejdík]]<ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Scott McCloud]] <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Dave Cooper]] <ref name= "lambiek.net12" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_koningsstraat27_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2015-present)|publisher=}}</ref>, [[Turtel Onli]] <ref name= "lambiek.net12" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_koningsstraat27_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2015-present)|publisher=}}</ref> and [[Derf Backderf]] <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net12" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_koningsstraat27_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2015-present)|publisher=}}</ref>. The shop and the informational website both have a strong focus on [[underground comics]], [[graphic novel]]s and [[autobiographical comics]]. The exhibitions can be profit or non-profit, depending on the subject of the exposition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/news/167/virtual_exhibition_willem_vleeschouwer.html#.VotY0VLxuNI|title=Virtual exhibition Willem Vleeschouwer|work=Lambiek Comic Shop}}</ref>
==History== Kees Kousemaker (1942-2010) was a Dutch comics expert, born in [[Steenbergen]], [[Netherlands]]. He first arose to prominence when he opened Lambiek in November 1968, the first specialized comic book store in Europe and the second oldest worldwide after [[Gary Arlington]]'s San Francisco Comic Book Company which was established earlier that year in April, according to the Lambiek website.<ref name="lambiek.net1">{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/infomenu/about_us.html|title=About the store - Lambiek Comic Shop|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/underground.htm |title=Comics History: Underground comix and the underground press |work=lambiek.net}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net2" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat104_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1968-1975)|publisher=}}</ref> Actually, an even older comic book store is known to have opened its doors in May 1967, George Henderson's Canadian, Toronto-based Memory Lane Books<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookdaily.com/championing_comics/progressive-shops/canadas-first-comic-shop/ |title=Canada’s 1st Comic Shop? |first=Scott | last=VanderPloeg |date=14 September 2011 |work=comicbookdaily.com}}</ref> (itself a continuation of the Viking Bookshop he had already opened on another location in the spring of 1966<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torontoist.com/2015/09/vintage-toronto-ads-memory-lane/ | title=Vintage Toronto Ads: Memory Lane – The story of "Captain George" Henderson, Toronto's first retailer to specialize in comic books. | first=Jamie |last=Bradburn | work=torontoist.com |date=2 September 2015}}</ref>), making Lambiek the third oldest store. All three stores had a strong focus on underground comics in common. With Memory Lane Books no longer in existence since the 1980s and the closure of Arlington's store in 2002,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://laughingsquid.com/gary-arlington-1938-2014-owner-of-the-first-comic-book-store-in-the-united-states/ |title=Gary Arlington (1938-2014), Owner of the First Comic Book Store in the United States |first=Lori | last=Dorn |date=6 February 2014 |work=laughingsquid.com}}</ref> Lambiek therefore has become the oldest comic book store still in existence as of 2017. <ref name= "lambiek.net2" />
As a result of his exhibitions and attention to the early work of young cartoonists such as [[Peter Pontiac]] and [[Joost Swarte]], he established collaborations and friendships with many Dutch and international artists, such as [[Will Eisner]]. <ref name= "lambiek.net4" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1980-1985)|publisher=}}</ref> In 1986 Lambiek established its famous [[Art museum|gallery]], where many comics artists could come and have heavily mediatized exhibitions of their work. The first expo revolved around the magazine ''[[RAW (magazine)|RAW]]'' and was co-organized by [[Joost Swarte]]. <ref name= "lambiek.net5" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat78_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1986-1989)|publisher=}}</ref>Kousemaker also published books about Dutch comic culture, such as ''Strip voor Strip'' (1970) <ref name= "lambiek.net2" /> and ''Stripleksikon der Lage Landen'' (1979). <ref name= "lambiek.net3" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat104_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (1975-1980)|publisher=}}</ref> He was also responsible for a special [[Yiddish]] edition of [[Will Eisner]]'s ''[[A Contract with God]]'' (1984), which was presented to the press in the presence of Eisner himself. <ref name= "lambiek.net4" />
Kees Kousemaker was also the instigator behind the ''Stripheldenbuurt'' in [[Almere]], a district where all the street names were named after famous cartoonists and comics characters. <ref name= "lambiek.net9" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat119.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2003-2005)|publisher=}}</ref> On 11 May 2006 he was knighted in the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]]. <ref name= "lambiek.net10" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2005-2010)|publisher=}}</ref>
Kousemaker died April 27, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/k/kousemaker.htm|title=Kees Kousemaker|date=1 January 1970|work=lambiek.net}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net10" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2005-2010)|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net11" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_2.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2010-2015)|publisher=}}</ref>
==Lambiek website== ===History=== Although '''lambiek.net''' is the store's main domain name, Lambiek started a website '''www.lambiek.com''' in 1994<ref name="lambiek.net1"/> when Kees started to store historical comic book info online. Throughout the 1990s and 2000s the site kept its original blue design, until Kousemaker's death in 2010. From August 2012 on, Kees Kousemaker's son Boris ordered a complete remake of the site, converting all existing information into databases.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/news/155/lambiek_s_revamped_website_kicks_off_.html#.VotcvFLxuNI|title=Lambiek's revamped website kicks off!|work=Lambiek Comic Shop}}</ref>
===Comiclopedia=== The ''Comiclopedia'' is an online encyclopedia which features biographical information and illustrations, comic strip images, album covers, frame grabs, and memorabilia about every individual comics artist whose name can be identified by signature. <ref name= "lambiek.net8" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_online_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek - Lambiek at Lambiek.net (1999-2004) |publisher=}}</ref> All artists are alphabetized and can both be looked up by name or by their nationality. The emphasis is mostly on comics artists, though [[cartoonist]]s, [[caricaturist]]s, [[animator]]s, [[illustrator]]s and/or celebrities who once drew comics themselves are also listed. Visitors can mail suggestions for new names, additions or corrections. <ref name= "lambiek.net8" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_online_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek - Lambiek at Lambiek.net (1999-2004) |publisher=}}</ref> As of 2018 more than 13.700 names have a page. <ref name= "lambiek.net8" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_online_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek - Lambiek at Lambiek.net (1999-2004) |publisher=}}</ref>
===History of comics sections=== The history section also includes an in-depth examination of [[Bulgarian comics]], researched and written by Vladimir Nedialkov, with additions by Stiliana Thepileva .<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/infomenu/faq.html?fcategory=Comiclopedia&fid=132|title=Lambiek Comic Shop|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/bulgarian.htm|title=History of Bulgarian Comics|publisher=}}</ref> The site also features a historical overview of the comics magazines ''[[Spirou (magazine)|Spirou]]'', ''[[Tintin (magazine)|Tintin]]'', ''[[Pif gadget]]'', ''[[Pilote]]'', and ''[[Wimmen's Comix]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/magazines/index.htm|title=Comic Magazines|publisher=}}</ref>
Lambiek also features separate articles about the [[Comics Code]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/code.htm|title=The Comics Code|publisher=}}</ref> [[Frederic Wertham]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/wertham_fredric.htm|title=Dr. Fredric Wertham|publisher=}}</ref> [[Disney comics]] artists around the world,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/disneyartists.htm|title=Disney comic artists in the Comiclopedia|publisher=}}</ref> [[Rolf Kauka]] artists,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/kauka.htm|title=Kauka artists in the Comiclopedia|publisher=}}</ref> [[erotic comics]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/erotic_comics.htm|title=Erotic Comics|publisher=}}</ref> [[newspaper strips]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/strips/index.htm|title=Early US Newspaper Comics|publisher=}}</ref> [[underground comics]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/underground.htm|title=Underground comix and the underground press|publisher=}}</ref> and [[webcomics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/webcomics.htm|title=Webcomics|publisher=}}</ref> There is also a column for thus unidentified comics where the site's owners ask visitors for help with identification of the anonymous artists or with providing more biographical info and/or illustrations about them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/help.htm|title=The Comiclopedia needs your help!|publisher=}}</ref>
==Awards== * In 2006 Kousemaker was the recipient of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] medal from the Netherlands for his special dedication to the history of comic books.<ref>[http://www.stripschap.nl/control.php?&topgroupname=stripnieuws&groupname=stripnieuws&subgroupname=nieuws&contentname=sn_artikel0001 Koninginnedag 2006: Opnieuw zijn striphelden koninklijk onderscheiden] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110203802/http://www.stripschap.nl/control.php |date=2007-11-10 }}</ref> <ref name= "lambiek.net10" >{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_kerkstraat132_1.htm|title=The History of Lambiek (2005-2010)|publisher=}}</ref> * Kousemaker also received the [[Will Eisner]] Spirit of Comics Retailer Award in 1997.<ref>[http://www.comic-con.org/cci/cci_eisners_spirit.shtml Comic-con.org Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911033848/http://www.comic-con.org/cci/cci_eisners_spirit.shtml |date=2007-09-11 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of online encyclopedias]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.lambiek.net/}} ** [https://www.lambiek.net/comics/story_of_lambiek.htm History of the comics store Lambiek.] ** [https://www.lambiek.net/comiclopedia.html Comiclopedia] ** [https://www.lambiek.net/comics/lambiek_online_1.htm History of the Comiclopedia.] ** [http://www.lambiek.net/comics/index.htm History of Dutch comics]

revision.text:
:''See [[Lists of Bible stories]]''.
'''New Testament stories''' are the [[pericope]]s or [[Narrative|stories]] from the [[New Testament]] of [[Christianity]].
{{Gospel Jesus}}
==The Gospels and the Life of Jesus== :'''For a list of all events in the life of Jesus, ''see [[Gospel harmony#A parallel harmony presentation|Gospel harmony]]''''' :For a list of parables told by Jesus, ''see [[Parables of Jesus#Examples|Parables of Jesus]]'' :For a list of miracles attributed to Jesus, ''see [[Miracles attributed to Jesus#List of miracles in the four Gospels|Miracles of Jesus]]''
==The Acts of the Apostles== :''From the [[Acts of the Apostles]]'' *[[Ascension of Christ]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|1:1:9|NIV}}) *[[Saint Matthias|Matthias]] replaced Judas ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|1:12-26|NIV}}) * [[Pentecost|The Day of Pentecost]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|2|NIV}}) *[[Ananias and Sapphira]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|5:1-11|NIV}}) *[[Seven Deacons|Seven Greeks appointed]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|6:1-7|NIV}}) *[[Saint Stephen|The Stoning of Stephen]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|6:8-7:60|NIV}}) *[[Philip the Evangelist|Preaching of Philip the Evangelist]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|8:4-40|NIV}}) *[[Simon Magus|Simon the Sorcerer]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|8:9-24|NIV}}) *[[Conversion of Paul the Apostle|Paul's Conversion]] on the Road to Damascus ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|9|NIV}}) *[[Peter's vision of a sheet with animals]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|10:9-16|NIV}}) *[[Centurion Cornelius|Conversion of Cornelius]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|10:1-48|NIV}}) *[[James, son of Zebedee]] executed ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|12:1-2|NIV}}) *[[Liberation of Saint Peter]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|12:3-19|NIV}}) *Death of Herod [[Agrippa I]] [44 AD] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|12:20-25|NIV}}) *[[Paul the Apostle#First missionary journey|Paul and Barnabas' first missionary journey]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|13-14|NIV}}) *The [[Council of Jerusalem]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|15:1-35|NIV}}) *Paul's [[Paul the Apostle#Second missionary journey|Second missionary journey]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|15:36-18:22|NIV}}) *Paul's [[Paul the Apostle#Third missionary journey|Third missionary journey]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|18:23-21:16|NIV}}) *Paul before [[Antonius Felix|Felix]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|24|NIV}}) *Paul before [[Porcius Festus|Festus]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|25:1-12|NIV}}) *Paul before [[Agrippa II]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|25:23-26:32|NIV}}) *Paul's [[Paul the Apostle#Arrest and death|Journey to Rome]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Acts|27-28|NIV}})
==Epistle to the Galatians== :''From the [[Epistle to the Galatians]]'' *[[Conversion of Paul the Apostle]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Galatians|1:11–24|NIV}}) *a [[Right hand of Christian fellowship|meeting]], possibly the [[Council of Jerusalem]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Galatians|2:1–10|NIV}}) *[[Incident at Antioch]] ({{Bibleverse-nb||Galatians|2:11–14|NIV}})
==Revelation== :'''For a list of events in the [[Book of Revelation]], ''see [[Events of Revelation]]'''''
==See also== * [[Chronology of Jesus]] *[[List of Hebrew Bible events]] *[[New Testament]]
{{Jesus footer|state=collapsed}}

[[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |coordinates = |country = |area served = Worldwide (except blocked countries) |founder = |chairman = Philip Rowley |chairperson = |president = |CEO = Lippe Oosterhof |services = [[Internet TV]] |international = yes |net income = [[US$]]3 million (2015) https://hired.com/companies/livestation |employees = 10 |parent = [[Microsoft Research]] |url = http://www.livestation.com/ |programming language = |ipv6 = |alexa = {{Decrease}} 81,758 ({{as of|2015|09|08|alt=September 2015}}){{cite web|url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/livestation.com |title= Livestation.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= September 9, 2015}} |website type = |advertising = No |registration = Mandatory (sign up / sign in via [[Facebook]] or [[Twitter]]); as of early-2015 |users = |language = English |launched = {{start date and age|2008|09|24}} |current status = Defunct (as of 23 November 2016) |native clients = |footnotes = }} {{Infobox Software | name = | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | author = | developer = Skinkers Ltd
[[Microsoft Research]]
Livestation Ltd | released = July 2007 (announced)
September 7, 2007 (IBC 2007 - Amsterdam)
February 12, 2008 (beta release)
September 24, 2008 (full release) | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | operating system = | platform = cross-platform including [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] '''Former:''' [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Apple Macintosh]], [[Linux]] | language = [[English language|English]] | status = | genre = [[Internet TV]] | license = [[Proprietary protocol|Proprietary]] | website = [http://www.livestation.com/ www.livestation.com] }} '''Livestation''' was a platform for distributing live television and radio broadcasts over a data network.{{cite web | url = http://www.livestation.com/channels | title = Live television and radio | accessdate = 2008-03-09 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091007225144/http%3A//www.livestation.com/channels | archivedate = 2009-10-07 | df = }} It was originally developed by Skinkers Ltd. and is now an independent company called Livestation Ltd. The service was originally based on peer-to-peer technology acquired from [[Microsoft Research]].{{cite web | url = http://www.livestation.com/broadcast_platform?tracker=main_menu | title = Scalable High Quality Solution | accessdate = 2008-05-14}} Between mid-June 2013 and mid-July Livestation was unavailable to some subscribers due to technical issues. In late 2016, the service closed down without notice.{{cite web|last1=N/A|first1=N/A|title=N/A|url=http://www.livestation.com|website=LiveStation|publisher=Livestation|accessdate=23 November 2016|ref=N/A}} ==Overview== Livestation aggregated international news channels online and offered them in a number of ways: * '''Free to watch:''' a number of channels could be watched for free on the Livestation website or on their desktop player, a freely downloadable video application that presented all the channels through one interface. * '''Premium service:''' some of the free channels were also available on a subscription basis both in higher quality (800kbit/s) and in lower (256kbit/s) delivered via an international content distribution network for higher reliability. * '''Mobile:''' Livestation launched BBC World News on the iPhone in 16 European countries and Al Jazeera English globally. The apps were available in the iPhone AppStore and stream the live TV channel 24/7 on both Wi-Fi and 3G connections. Livestation broadcast streams encoded in [[VC-1]] format (Livestation is not currently using peer-to-peer). Playback controls were overlaid on top of the video stream. Unlike services such as [[Joost]] which offer video on demand channels, Livestation streams live broadcasts.{{cite web | url = http://soapbox.msn.com/video.aspx?vid=4da4263c-68a0-411f-8eec-58dc81bf22da | title = Livestation demonstration | accessdate = 2007-07-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070707053000/http://soapbox.msn.com/video.aspx?vid=4da4263c-68a0-411f-8eec-58dc81bf22da | archivedate = 2007-07-07 | df = }} Livestation provided a website, mobile website and native applications for iOS, Android, Nokia and Blackberry handsets. Early models of Samsung TV were also supported. They also provided desktop software available for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Mac OS|Mac]] (including PowerPC) and [[Linux]]. The cross-platform compatibility of the desktop software was facilitated by the [[Qt (toolkit)|Qt]] framework. Social networking features were later added that include the ability to chat with other viewers and also find out what others are watching through a user generated rating system. You could search and select the available channels either from the website, or from within the software. In the first quarter of 2011 by 1047 percent, resulting in the first profitable quarter in its history.[http://blog.livestation.com/index.php/2011/04/the-livestation-revolution/ The Livestation revolution] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110416014305/http://blog.livestation.com/index.php/2011/04/the-livestation-revolution/ |date=2011-04-16 }}. Livestation Blog. 11 April 2011. Retrieved on 21 April 2011. Between mid-June and mid-July 2013, Livestation suffered a prolonged series of technical issues and was unavailable to some users. In early 2015, Livestation re-branded their entire site changing what channels were offered and bringing in an interactive feature. Some stations on the app were not on the mainsite and vice versa. == Available channels == Stations available until closure and former live TV news channels in the global offering (which comes with a default installation) included,http://support.livestation.com/customer/portal/articles/1842844-list-of-available-news-channels- as of 2016: * {{flagicon|PHL}} [[ABS-CBN News Channel]] * revision.comment: Point "common knowledge" at the "(logic)" version of the page.
revision.text:
'''Mutual knowledge''' in [[game theory]] is information known by all participatory agents. However, unlike [[Common knowledge (logic)|common knowledge]], a related topic, mutual knowledge does not require that all agents are aware that this knowledge is mutual.<ref>{{Cite book|edition = Spring 2014|title = Common Knowledge|url = http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2014/entries/common-knowledge/|date = 2014-01-01|first = Peter|last = Vanderschraaf|first2 = Giacomo|last2 = Sillari|editor-first = Edward N.|editor-last = Zalta}}</ref> All common knowledge is mutual knowledge, but not all mutual knowledge is common knowledge. Mutual knowledge can arise accidentally, due to a failure to design the game properly, so all players independently discover this mutual knowledge, or deliberately, due to the expected course of the game.
== The difference between mutual knowledge and common knowledge ==
The difference is crucial in a co-operation game. For example, in the game depicted below, with a random event determining the payoff matrix, both players, being fully rational, presume the more likely option to have occurred. However, suppose each player separately finds out that the random number, which was created privately and which determines the payoff matrix, was 1. However, neither are told that the other player is also aware of this.
Player A presumes Player B is not aware the random number is 1. They then observe that if the random number is 2-100, the best choice for B is always b1. So they choose a2, which would give them the best possible payoff in this matrix. Symmetrically, Player B presumes Player A expects the random numbers 2-100 and chooses a1, so B chooses b2. As a result, the players had a final result of (1, a2, b2), with a payoff of 1 for both - the lowest possible payoff (total or individual).
Now suppose that it is common knowledge that the random number is 1 - that is, both players are also aware that the other player knows the random number is 1, in addition to knowing this themselves. Given this, the best choice for A is a1, with an average of 6.5, and the best choice for B is b1, with an average of 6.5 also, giving an outcome of (1, a1, b1) with a payoff of 8 for both - the highest possible total payoff.
Common knowledge tends to lead to co-operative behavior more often than purely mutual knowledge, which can often lead to anti-cooperative behavior as shown in the example above, as the participants are aware that the knowledge is mutual knowledge and can all decide on behalf of this knowledge.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The psychology of coordination and common knowledge.|url = http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0037037|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|pages = 657-676|volume = 107|issue = 4|doi = 10.1037/a0037037|first = Kyle A.|last = Thomas|first2 = Peter|last2 = DeScioli|first3 = Omar Sultan|last3 = Haque|first4 = Steven|last4 = Pinker}}</ref> This works best in a symmetric game, like the left matrix below. {| class="wikitable" |+The payoff matrices !A game ! colspan="2" |Random number: 1 ! colspan="2" |Random number: 2-100 |- |Payoff (A, B) |A chooses option a1 |A chooses option a2 |A chooses option a1 |A chooses option a2 |- |B chooses option b1 |8,8 |10,5 |3,4 |2,3 |- |B chooses option b2 |5,10 |1,1 |4,3 |3,2 |}
== Bibliography == <references />{{gametheory-stub}}
[[Category:Game theory]]

{{unreferenced|date=June 2016}}
The term '''panel operator''' generally relates to any person who is employed to operate a broadcast console. This term is more often used in the radio industry. In the U.S., insiders refer to a broadcast console as a 'board', and in turn, refer to those operating it as a '''board operator'''.
Panel operators usually do not have on-air speaking roles, and focus only on presenting the program to air technically. People who operate the panel as well as having a speaking role on a show are often known as [[anchors]]. Most music announcers these days operate the panel as well as presenting their shift to air.
Panel operators are usually responsible for (but not limited to) the following duties:
* Keeping talent informed of the show's progress * Keeping the show on time, and timing out to news and other programming elements * Playing music, [[Radio commercial|commercial]]s and programming elements at appropriate times * Operating the on-air telephone system * Co-ordinating and inserting elements such as [[traffic report]]s * Ensuring that talent [[microphone]] levels are acceptable, and switching microphones on and off
Panel operators need to be technically able, good at working under pressure and dealing with talent egos, conscious of time constraints and able to think quickly when something goes wrong. The entire on-air presentation of the show is reliant upon their ability.
[[Category:Media occupations]]
